Title: Borel measures on $\omega_1$.
Content:
Say $\omega_1$ is the first uncountable ordinal, and let $X=[0,\omega_1]$ (with the order topology). Elsewhere it is said that Rao & Rao proved a result that is easily seen to be equivalent to this: Lemma (Rao & Rao). If $
u$ is a Borel probability measure on $X$ and $
u(\{j\})=0$ for every $j\in X$ then $
u$ is the Dieudonne measure. Which is the same as saying that $
u(K)=1$ for every uncountable compact $K$ . I find this hard to believe. Stuck at home right now with no access to the paper; anyone have a hint? A brief reminder re the Dieudonne measure: Say $M_1$ is the class of all $E\subset X$ such that $E\cup\{\omega_1\}$ contains an uncountable compact set; let $M_0=\{X\setminus E:E\in M_1\}$ and $M=M_1\cup M_0$ . Then $M$ is a $\sigma$ -algebra containing every Borel set (hint: it's clear that $M$ contains every compact set); noting that $M_1\cap M_0=\emptyset$ we define the Dieudonne measure $\lambda$ on $M$ by $$\lambda(E)= egin{cases}1,&(E\in M_1),\0,&(E\in M_0).\end{cases}$$ See for example  Exercise 18 in Chapter 2 of Rudin Real and Complex Analysis ...
AcceptedAnswer:
The key ingredient is the following theorem of Ulam: Theorem : Let $\mu$ be a finite measure defined on the entire power set $P(\omega_1)$ which vanishes on singletons.  Then $\mu=0$ . In particular, we can apply this to your setup as follows. Corollary : Let $
u$ be a Borel probability measure on $\omega_1$ which vanishes on singletons, and suppose $U\subset\omega_1$ can be written as a disjoint union of bounded open sets.  Then $
u(U)=0$ . Proof of Corollary from Theorem : Suppose $U= igcup_{\alpha<\omega_1} U_\alpha$ where the $U_\alpha$ are disjoint, bounded, and open.  Define a measure $\mu$ on $P(\omega_1)$ by $\mu(A)=
u( igcup_{\alpha\in A} U_\alpha)$ (this is well-defined since such a union is always open and a measure since the $U_\alpha$ are disjoint).  Then $\mu$ vanishes on singletons since each $U_\alpha$ is bounded.  Thus by the Theorem, $\mu=0$ , and in particular $
u(U)=\mu(\omega_1)=0$ . Now to prove your Lemma, let $K\subset\omega_1$ be any closed unbounded set and let $U=\omega_1\setminus K$ .  Enumerating the elements of $K$ in order as $(c_\alpha)_{\alpha<\omega_1}$ , then we can partition $U$ into the bounded open sets $[0,c_0)$ and $(c_\alpha,c_{\alpha+1})$ as $\alpha$ ranges over all of $\omega_1$ .  Thus by the Corollary, $
u(U)=0$ and so $
u(K)=1$ . Finally, here is a proof of the Theorem.  Suppose $\mu$ is nonzero.  For each $\alpha<\omega_1$ , let $f_\alpha:\alpha	o\omega$ be an injection.  For $ eta<\omega_1$ and $n<\omega$ , let $A_{ eta,n}=\{\alpha:f_\alpha( eta)=n\}$ .  Note that for fixed $ eta$ , $ igcup_n A_{ eta,n}=\omega_1\setminus( eta+1)$ (since $f_\alpha( eta)$ is defined as long as $\alpha> eta$ ), which has full measure since $\mu$ vanishes on countable sets.  Thus for each $ eta$ there is some $n$ such that $A_{ eta,n}$ has positive measure.  Since there are uncountably many $ eta$ 's and only countably many $n$ 's, then must be some fixed $n$ such that $A_{ eta,n}$ has positive measure for uncountably many different $ eta$ .  But for fixed $n$ , the sets $A_{ eta,n}$ are disjoint since the functions $f_\alpha$ are injective.  Since a finite measure cannot have an uncountable family of disjoint sets of positive measure, this is a contradiction.
